Author: Roisin O'Connor & Elizabeth Aubrey
Quote: But Alessia Cara triumphs ... abandoning her R&B roots in place of a <proficiency>snarling, agile vocal performance,</proficiency> with a <genre>delicious pinch of pop-punk</genre> on the verses providing additional spice.

Author: Sam Walker-Smart
Quote: Mac DeMarco['s] hella fun stab at 'Enter Sandman' add[s] some <genre>garage rock panache</genre> to this guitar shop classic. It's heavy, it's goofy, and he sounds like he's having the time of his life with it.

Author: Mark Beaumont
Quote: Mac DeMarco's <proficiency>spirited if wobbly</proficiency> attempt to give it its full metal dues

Author: Joe Gross
Quote: (Then again, <loyalty>nobody, including ... Mac DeMarco, go very afield</loyalty> with that one.)

Author: Joe Daly
Quote: Ghost transform Enter Sandman into a <genre>euphoric slice of 70s hard rock</genre> with <instrumentation>snarling riffs, piano-driven melodies</instrumentation> and Papa's witchy, layered vocals.

Author: Max Morin
Quote: Ghost have definitely been waiting to cover "Enter Sandman" forever and it comes out with their <memorability>distinct organ-heavy energy</memorability>.

Author: Mark Beaumont
Quote: with the rear of the field made up by Ghost's <genre>gloss-rock pantomime</genre> version

Author: Joe Gross
Quote: (Then again, <loyalty>nobody, including Ghost ... go very afield</loyalty> with that one.)

Author: Joe Daly
Quote: Colombia's <reputation>Grammy-collecting megastar</reputation>, Juanes, <genre>funks up Enter Sandman with a bit of Latin flavour</genre>

Author: Joe Daly
Quote: ...but you'd still be <memorability>hard-pressed to remember it</memorability> among the numerous other versions.

Author: Max Morin
Quote: ...Juanes, the Colombian pop musician who returns to his roots for a <genre>reggaeton</genre> "Enter Sandman".

Author: Joe Gross
Quote: (Then again, <loyalty>nobody, including  ... Juanes ... go very afield</loyalty> with that one.)

Author: Max Morin
Quote: Rina Sawayama turns the same song into a <genre>thrash/dance tune.</genre>

Author: Brad Sanders
Quote: The spirit of the release is better captured by the thumping, maximalist pop of Rina Sawayama's "Enter Sandman"

Author: Steve Lampiris
Quote: It's not that Weezer's "Sandman" ... (among others) are bad; instead, they're simply uninteresting. <loyalty>They don't add anything new.</loyalty> "It's a little stock," in other words.

Author: Joe Daly
Quote: But the hits outweigh the misses by a mile, especially when you've got <reputation>hitters like ... Weezer ... in the line-up</reputation>.

Author: Max Morin
Quote: <memorability>Don't miss<memorability> more covers by ... Weezer

Author: Mark Beaumont
Quote: Weezer's <instrumentation>power-chord overload</instrumentation

Author: Brad Sanders
Quote: Weezer, who scored an improbable hit in 2018 by covering Toto, <loyalty>sleepwalk through a carbon copy of "Enter Sandman" that follows the original note-for-note</loyalty> except when they interpolate a lick from "Buddy Holly."

Author: Joe Gross
Quote: Weezer doing "Enter Sandman" <reputation>sounds, well, exactly like Weezer</reputation> covering "Enter Sandman"

Author: Mark Beaumont
Quote: Both <interpretation>trump Sam Fender's soul effort</interpretation>

Quote: Closely related, Jason Isbell and The 400 Unit turn Sad But True into a <genre>boozy roadhouse shakedown</genre>.

Quote: but face stiff competition from Jason Isbell And The 400 Unit (<genre>demented skiffle rock</genre>)

Author: Joe Gross

Quote: but face stiff competition from ... the Mexican Institute Of Sound (<genre>carnival freak rave</genre>)

Author: Mark Beaumont
Quote: Cage The Elephant's <interpretation>take on 'The Unforgiven',</interpretation> giving James Hetfield's struggles with religion upon his mother's death a <genre>cultured psych-rock soundtrack</genre>, does the trick straight off the bat.

Author: Steve Lampiris
Quote: <genre>Indian electronica and rap</genre> ("The Unforgiven" from Vishal Dadlani and DIVINE)

Author: Max Morin

Author: Mark Beaumont
Quote: Yet further variants on the <genre>doom ballad theme from the likes of Vishal Dadlani & Divine (intense)</genre> ... feel like vast overkill.

Author: Max Morin

Author: Mark Beaumont
Quote: Yet further variants on the <genre>doom ballad theme from the likes of ... Diet Cig (grungy)</genre> ... feel like vast overkill.

Author: Brad Sanders

Author: Joe Daly
Quote: Ha*Ash's version of The Unforgiven – a <genre>dreamy slice of acoustic balladry</genre> that feels like the theme to a mythic quest.

Author: Mark Beaumont
Quote: Yet further variants on the <genre>doom ballad theme from the likes of ... Ha*Ash (folk-poppy)</genre> ... feel like vast overkill.

Author: Sam Walker-Smart
Quote: Ghanaian-American singer-songwriter Moses Sumney brings <interpretation>soul and pathos</interpretation> to 'The Unforgiven,' a true highlight and the most beautiful moment of the set.

Author: Mark Beaumont
Quote: Yet further variants on the <genre>doom ballad theme from the likes of ... Moses Sumney (soulful and fiddly-fingered)</genre> feel like vast overkill.

Author: Brad Sanders

Author: Max Morin

Author: Mark Beaumont

Author: Brad Sanders

Quote: [T]here's a refreshing stretch where ... Chase & Status ... remould the eastern textures of 'Wherever I May Roam' into </genre>modernist dancefloor destroyers</genre>

Author: Mark Beaumont

Author: Mark Beaumont

Author: Steve Lampiris

Author: Max Morin

Author: Joe Daly
Quote: Mongolian marauders The Hu check in with a slamming Through The Never, <interpretation>sung in their native tongue and played with the wild, surging ferocity of a bloodthirsty horde riding into battle</interpretation>.

Author: Max Morin
Quote: But it's The Hu's <memorability>Mongolian-language "Through The Never"</memorability> that will send fans into fits of musical ecstasy.

Author: Max Morin
Quote: <reputation>rising R&B star</reputation> Tomi Owó, whose version of "Through The Never" manages to <instrumentation>balance metal riffs with her angelic voice</instrumentation>.

Author: Fred Thomas
Quote: Phoebe Bridgers' <interpretation>especially delicate reading</interpretation>

Author: Sam Walker-Smart
Quote: For something completely different, we have Phoebe Bridgers <genre>baroque-pop</genre> go at 'Nothing Else Matters,' <instrumentation>twinkling keys and somber strings</instrumentation> adding some welcome ambiance to the power ballad.

Author: Roisin O'Connor & Elizabeth Aubrey
Quote: On "Nothing Else Matters", Bridgers opens with a <instrumentation>startlingly beautiful piano motif</instrumentation> reminiscent of Chilly Gonzales's delicate work. Where many have attempted to capture the imposing volume Metallica brought to The Black Album, Bridgers <interpretation>takes the stripped-down route, with magnificent results</interpretation>.

Author: Steve Lampiris
Quote: Phoebe Bridgers, whose <interpretation>stunning and haunting</interpretation> <genre>chamber music reading</genre> of "Nothing" is the best of the dozen ...

Author: Max Morin
Quote: Phoebe Bridgers is here to chill things out with her <instrumentation>piano</instrumentation> and <genre>indie-rock production</genre>

Author: Mark Beaumont
Quote: Phoebe Bridgers produces a <genre>far more gorgeous, vaporous junk</genre> <instrumentation>piano</instrumentation> take

Author: Brad Sanders
Quote: Phoebe Bridgers' delicate version <interpretation>feels like a Punisher outtake</interpretation>

Author: Joe Gross
Quote: Phoebe Bridgers (<instrumentation>piano and strings</instrumentation>)

Author: Fred Thomas
Quote: a <uniqueness><uniqueness>staggering 12 versions</uniqueness></uniqueness> of "Nothing Else Matters" by everyone from <reputation>Miley Cyrus (appearing along with Yo-Yo Ma, Elton John, and other friends)</reputation> ... and more.

Author: Sam Walker-Smart
Quote: <reputation>Miley Cyrus, Elton John, the Chili's Chad Smith, and Metallica's own Robert Trujillo join forces</reputation> for an absolutely stacked cover of 'Nothing Else Matters,' Cyrus channeling Stevie Nicks for some <proficiency>serious 80s wind-machine worthy epicness</proficiency>.

Author: Roisin O'Connor & Elizabeth Aubrey
Quote: We'd already seen Miley Cyrus spark calls for her to abandon pop altogether in favour of a new era as a fully fledged rock star, thanks to her <reputation>Glastonbury performance of "Nothing Else Matters"</reputation>. Her recorded version is just as impressive[.]

Author: Steve Lampiris
Quote: worth checking out, [...] <reputation>Miley Cyrus' fascinating mess—featuring six artists including Elton John, Yo-Yo Ma, and Chad Smith</reputation>

Author: Joe Daly
Quote: <reputation>Miley Cyrus's collaboration with Elton John and others</reputation> on Nothing Else Matters is one of the more memorable tracks

Author: Max Morin
Quote: All the attention is right on the centre of the album. It's where <reputation>Miley Cyrus, Elton John, Yo-yo Ma and Chad Smith of Red Hot Chili Peppers deliver the star take</reputation>. Miley Cyrus has reinvented herself several times at this point, but her recent transformation into The Hard Rock Queen of Karaoke has been unexpected and genuinely great. She has a harsh edge on her voice that has been hiding up to this point, a <interpretation>bluesy rasp that calls to mind PJ Harvey, Courtney Barnett and James Hetfield's own bark</interpretation>. As their version of "Nothing Else Matters" swells to its climax, it's clear that this is the only track on The Blacklist that can actually be compared to the original.

Author: Mark Beaumont
Quote: The <reputation>marquee names are instantly apparent: Miley Cyrus ropes in Elton John and Chad Smith (among others)</reputation>, complete with <composition>unnecessary violin solo</composition>

Author: Brad Sanders
Quote: Miley Cyrus <reputation>enlists Elton John and Yo-Yo Ma for no reason other than she can</reputation>

Author: Joe Gross
Quote:
Current covers queen Miley Cyrus assembles an <reputation>all-star cast for her version,
including Eton John, Red Hot Chili Peppers drummer Chad Smith and current Metallica bassist Robert Trujillo,</reputation> her voice at the <proficiency>perfect grit</proficiency> for the iconic ballad.

Author: Mark Beaumont
Quote: <reputation>Depeche Mode's Dave Gahan</reputation> was born to sing it, swathed in an <genre>electronic miasma</genre>.

Author: Joe Gross
Quote: <reputation>Depeche Mode singer Dave Gahan</reputation> (<genre>maximum lounge crooner</genre>)

Author: Fred Thomas
Quote: a <uniqueness><uniqueness>staggering 12 versions</uniqueness></uniqueness> of "Nothing Else Matters" by everyone from ... My Morning Jacket ... and more.

Author: Steve Lampiris
Quote: My Morning Jacket turning it into a <genre>lighthearted ditty</genre> that's ready-made for car commercials.

Author: Max Morin
Quote: But the bottom has to be My Morning Jacket, who turn "Nothing Else Matters" into a <genre>pop rock tune that sounds weak and lacking</genre> in bite at the same time. It's the soundtrack to a bad commercial interrupting your YouTube playlist.

Author: Mark Beaumont
Quote: Kudos to My Morning Jacket and (oh yes) Roxette for banging out <genre>pop versions below four minutes</genre>

Quote: <reputation>Swedish pop pioneers Roxette</reputation> (do the rest, please)

Quote: a <uniqueness><uniqueness>staggering 12 versions</uniqueness></uniqueness> of "Nothing Else Matters" by everyone from ... Darius Rucker and more.

Quote: a <uniqueness>staggering 12 versions</uniqueness> of "Nothing Else Matters" by everyone from ... TRESOR ... and more.

Author: Fred Thomas

Author: Mark Beaumont
Quote: Special mention must go to Goodnight, Texas ... <uniqueness>the only [act] to offer to cover 'Of Wolf And Man'</uniqueness>

Author: Brad Sanders
Quote: On a 53-track album, they can't all be winners ... A group called Goodnight, Texas brings a <genre>stomp-clap-hey</genre> to "Of Wolf and Man."

Author: Sam Walker-Smart
Quote: IDLES pummel 'The God That Failed' into their wheelhouse, <instrumentation>snarling guitars and sparse bass</instrumentation> <interpretation>transforming the song into something wholly new and completely thrilling</interpretation>.

Author: Max Morin

Author: Mark Beaumont
Quote: IDLES deliver a <interpretation>sonic slap in the face</interpretation> with 'The God That Failed'

Author: Brad Sanders
Quote: IDLES turn "The God That Failed" into a <genre>bug-eyed post-punk exorcism</genre>

Author: Fred Thomas

Author: Roisin O'Connor & Elizabeth Aubrey
Quote: jazz virtuoso Kamasi Washington's <interpretation>transcendent take</interpretation> on "My Friend of Misery"

Author: Brad Sanders
Quote: Kamasi Washington pulls off the most impressive feat of the record, discovering a <genre>swirling spiritual jazz workout</genre> in the <uniqueness>little-loved "My Friend of Misery"</uniqueness" and enlisting vocalist Patrice Quinn to <interpretation>breathe new life</interpretation> into Hetfield's cynical lyric.

Author: Joe Gross
Quote: Kamasi Washington turns it into shockingly great electric fusion with singer Patrice Quinn reworking James Hetfield's lyrics into something for the Village Vanguard.

Author: Fred Thomas
